content:
After attending a few Rustc Reading Club sessions, I have an interest in trying to do something on the compiler. This might be as small as trying to add some more documentation to parts of code we've read through, or finding some task related to the name resolver. However, I'm still not confident in my abilities to handle the full contribution process: I don't know what's expected of a PR, how the "language" of compiler contributions work, and if I could even add something meaningful that isn't just bloat.

I had an idea of something that might help reduce this barrier for new contributors. A session (either part of the reading club or a different initiative if need be) where there are one or more leaders, and several participants of different skill levels. Using a tool like VS Code Liveshare could allow this group to peer program together. The participants could see the code diff as they go, the leaders could suggest improvements on parts of code, and the commit can include each of the participants as a "collaborator" (tracked by their email). Then each participant could be part of the PR process, and have their first commit to the main repo.

This is more or less just brainstorming, but I wanted to just mention it since I'd love to see new contributors coming from these reading clubs :) (a proper graduation!)
Love this idea. I'd be interested in joining :smile:

Sean Chen (he/him) said:

Love this idea. I'd be interested in joining :smile:

Which part would you lead?

Doc Jones said:

Sean Chen (he/him) said:

Love this idea. I'd be interested in joining :smile:

Which part would you lead?

I should probably caveat my interest with "I'm interested, but with a newborn, I'm not even 100% sure my bandwidth would allow me to join/lead something" :sweat_smile:

Sean Chen (he/him) said:

I should probably caveat my interest with "I'm interested, but with a newborn, I'm not even 100% sure my bandwidth would allow me to join/lead something" :sweat_smile:

Given I have experience with you leading peer programming sessions, I know you can do it. Think about a part of this you want to lead and get back to us. You wouldn't need to do all of it and it needn't be as formal as a class. :)
It's not a question about whether I can, it's a question of whether I have time :smile:

Sean Chen (he/him) said:

It's not a question about whether I can, it's a question of whether I have time :smile:

The same dilemma that all potential leaders have, btw. :). Fingers crossed and hope for the months ahead.

Forest Anderson [he/him] said:

I had an idea of something that might help reduce this barrier for new contributors. A session (either part of the reading club or a different initiative if need be) where there are one or more leaders, and several participants of different skill levels. Using a tool like VS Code Liveshare could allow this group to peer program together. The participants could see the code diff as they go, the leaders could suggest improvements on parts of code, and the commit can include each of the participants as a "collaborator" (tracked by their email). Then each participant could be part of the PR process, and have their first commit to the main repo.

This is more or less just brainstorming, but I wanted to just mention it since I'd love to see new contributors coming from these reading clubs :) (a proper graduation!)

Is this video something close to what you have in mind? @Esteban KÃ¼ber recorded,
Hacking on rustc - Negative literals in indexing expressions

It doesn't include the mob programming bit, but it does have part of the idea, I think. There is a group that does mob programming in rust and I agree for people new to contributing learning the process of landing a PR would be quite valuable. There is bound to be demand for this. I would want to attend.

I, also, agree that it is a separate initiative from the reading club.

Will you organize it, @Forest Anderson [he/him] ?

I would be interested in participating, we could maybe pick a few issues and have a poll then pick a date and work on the issue together over VsCode Liveshare or something? (I haven't been checking Zulip as frequently so feel free to liberally @ me)
